post.author: Mike
post.title: Delta Begins Changing its SkyMiles Program for Flights in 2015
post.content:
Airline rewards may not matter very much to casual fliers, but if you're one of the people that travels across the country on a regular basis, then you should be familiar with this breakdown of the new 2015 Delta SkyMiles program.

What's Changing?

The biggest change to the program is the way that customers will be able to earn miles - Delta has announced that miles will be awarded based on the price of the ticket, not the distance traveled. The announced distribution is as follows:

  • For General SkyMiles Members: 5 Reward Miles per Dollar
  • For Delta SkyMiles Credit Card Members: 7 Reward Miles per Dollar

The average fare for a round-trip flight inside of America was about $355 in 2012 - while prices have changed slightly, and will continue to do so, this means that rewards members can expect to average around 1800 reward miles per-flight (at the General level - Credit Card members will be higher). The general trend of increased ticket prices may raise this estimate somewhat.

Redeeming Rewards

Delta has also made a number of changes to the way that you can redeem rewards. They've announced that there will be no blackout dates for the miles used, and that award tickets can be used on any Delta flight.

Additionally, they're increasing both the number of redemption levels and the number of Award Seats that will be available on a given flight, making it much easier for most fliers to redeem their miles. While costs within the market can change with little or no notice, the awards calendar and comparison shop options have been created to help you figure out whether it's worth spending miles on a flight... or saving them for a better time.

What Isn't Changing?

The Medallion rewards system is remaining largely unchanged, with qualification continuing to grow based on the number of miles flown (not the price of the tickets). However, Delta has added a requirement for expenses on Delta flights, which should not have a significant impact on your ability to qualify for this particular program.

On top of this, many of the reward requirements (especially at the lowest levels) aren't changing - the breakdown of the new 2015 Delta SkyMiles program noted that 25,000 miles will continue to be the lowest redemption level on basic flights, which averages to around 14 flights to redeem the points at the estimated reward miles per flight.

As before, flights to destinations that are further away will continue to require more rewards miles for a trip - though, considering the additional costs of tickets to destinations that are further away, you may be able to reach reward levels faster than you expect if you travel on a regular basis.

What Else Should You Know?

Our breakdown of the new 2015 Delta SkyMiles program did notice several more things that you should be aware of before you start signing up for your next few flights.

First, Delta does have a system for calculating rewards when flights aren't being paid in US Dollars. The prices of the tickets will be checked against the IATA exchange rate over the last five days, helping to find the best estimate of the ticket's price in US Dollars while insulating both sides from most changes in currency values.

Miles and rewards can also be earned on flights with Delta's partners, subject to the details of the program and primarily based on a combination of fare paid and distance flown. Delta has yet to announce all of the details of this program, so keep watching this blog for more information as it's announced.

Disclaimer: As always for the airline industry, many things are subject to change - especially in regards to pricing, which can and will have an effect on rewards programs and how fast certain things can be earned. The estimates provided in this post are only estimates, and you should not rely on them too much. For more information on the breakdown of the new 2015 Delta SkyMiles program, check out their official website and be sure to read all of the terms and conditions for the program.

comment.author: Sheilah Vandawalker
comment.content: This is getting a bit more subjective, but I much prefer the Zune Marketplace. The interface is colorful, has more flair, and some cool features like 'Mixview' that let you quickly see related albums, songs, or other users related to what you're listening to. Clicking on one of those will center on that item, and another set of "neighbors" will come into view, allowing you to navigate around exploring by similar artists, songs, or users. Speaking of users, the Zune "Social" is also great fun, letting you find others with shared tastes and becoming friends with them. You then can listen to a playlist created based on an amalgamation of what all your friends are listening to, which is also enjoyable. Those concerned with privacy will be relieved to know you can prevent the public from seeing your personal listening habits if you so choose.

comment.author: Andrew Pelt
comment.content: Zune and iPod: Most people compare the Zune to the Touch, but after seeing how slim and surprisingly small and light it is, I consider it to be a rather unique hybrid that combines qualities of both the Touch and the Nano. It's very colorful and lovely OLED screen is slightly smaller than the touch screen, but the player itself feels quite a bit smaller and lighter. It weighs about 2/3 as much, and is noticeably smaller in width and height, while being just a hair thicker.
